awd_abstract_narration:
Many neuroscientists explain learning as a simple change in the number and/or strength of specialized connections between nerve cells called synapses. This research project tests a new idea, that learning also importantly involves molecular changes in other parts of nerve cells which control the production of electrical activity required for these cells to communicate with each other. Learning is studied in the context of how young songbirds learn to sing, which happens in a similar way to how humans learn to speak, play a musical instrument, or produce any complicated sequence of behavior. Using a combination of behavioral observation and recording together with anatomical, physiological, molecular, computational and statistical techniques, the research team will test the hypothesis that developmental singing changes are accompanied by changes in cell electrical activity that are not located at synapses. They will also identify the mechanistic basis for these electrical changes. This research will reveal important new details about how the brain can store learned information for an entire lifetime. It will also provide student research assistants with broad multidisciplinary training, as well as developing new analytical software and computational models that will benefit the broader neuroscience community (these will be made freely available through a publically-accessible web site). Neuroscience and mathematics videos tagged to specific State-mandated high school learning objectives will also be produced, which will be made available to teachers via a cataloged State portal. Finally, the research team conducts a wide variety of community education programs specifically related to neuroscience, birdsong, and learning.  These activities include programs for K-12 schools as well as a scholarly course for senior citizens.

Much is known about the brain areas and circuits that underlie birdsong learning. Consequently, scientists know where to look for learning-induced changes (an area named HVC), but they do not know what neural changes encode the auditory memories of song. The proposed research tests the novel hypothesis that changes in specific, non-synaptic ionic currents in HVC neurons contribute to the encoding of auditory memories. Songbird auditory learning can be readily manipulated by controlling exposure to a tutor song. Preliminary data show that the intrinsic cell body/axonal channel properties of HVC neurons change in an experience-dependent manner during song development. The research team's recent characterization and modeling of the ionic currents that determine the physiology of HVC neurons in the adult finch now allow for the proposed developmental studies. Proposed studies will test hypotheses about the developmental emergence of specific ionic currents as they relate to sensory learning. This will lead to testable hypotheses about the underlying molecular mechanisms responsible for this learning. As part of this project, the team will also correct mistaken views about HVC of female zebra finches. Long thought to lack male-typical connectivity, new data show that female and male HVC have the same cell types and patterns of extrinsic connectivity. Since females show auditory learning of tutor song, but do not sing, analysis of female HVC will provide a critical test of the proposed hypotheses. Together, the proposed experiments will provide clues to fundamental questions about how early sensory information is stored as a stable memory trace that lasts a lifetime.

por.por_cntn:
Our project outcomes contribute to two general scientific questions: 1) what goes on in the brain when learning takes place and 2) are there identifiable sex differences in brains that account for the fact that only male zebra finches produce a learned song.  Along the way, we developed methodologies in analyzing the electrical properties of neurons which were applied to studies of neural development.  

1.  Learning: Models of learning commonly focus on changes in the strength of synaptic connections. Our work, however, shows that variation in the intrinsic electrical properties of neurons (ion channels) may also produce changes in the function of neural circuits. Our experimental results showed learning-related changes in the intrinsic physiology of neurons in the cortical premotor nucleus HVC (acronym is name) of the zebra finch, an area key to the learning and production of song. Consequently, models of learning and memory should consider intrinsic plasticity of neurons as a possible contributor to how the nervous system encodes new information or novel behaviors, not simply changes in the strength of synaptic connections.

Applying our analysis more broadly, we also showed that the intrinsic properties of neurons change over the course of development in a fundamental auditory sensory processing area. Many have modeled the function of neural circuits based on physiological responses recorded in vitro and these are commonly recorded in young subjects for the practical reason of greater slice viability. Our work shows that these models may be flawed owing to developmental changes in ion channels. That is, connectivity may appear “adult like”, but the intrinsic properties of neurons may be quite different, and these ion channels may undergo experience-dependent changes during development.

2. Sex differences in the brain. Since only male zebra finches produce a learned song (females produce social calls, but do not sing), we compared the connectivity and intrinsic properties of neurons in the song control system of both male and female birds. This work unexpectedly showed that female birds possess the same general vocal circuitry as males and that female neurons show many more similarities than differences in the intrinsic properties of neurons that control vocalization. The results of behavioral experiments in females suggest that sex differences in behavior may emerge not because a brain network is present or absent in one of the sexes, but that the same network can have different behavioral functions in each sex.     

Broader impacts:  In addition to the development and public access of our neuronal models and analysis methods, our work has contributed to the development of a broadly trained scientific workforce and has contributed to a greater focus on neuroscience education at Florida State University (FSU). For example, our broad multidisciplinary training led one postdoc to a job at a company that uses biosimulation to increase efficiency of clinical trials and drug development. One of our PhD students is now a Senior Science Writer & Scientific Communications Liaison at Fred Hutch in Seattle, WA and another former student is a Machine Learning Research Scientist at Senseye, Inc. in Austin, TX.  Thus, in addition to training students pursuing traditional academic science, our training contributes to a workforce that requires multidisciplinary skills outside of the general academic research lab. At the local level, our group leader (Johnson) was integral to the development of an undergraduate Neuroscience degree at FSU. First offered in 2018, this degree has grown to over 500 majors and resulted in the hiring of multiple Neuroscience faculty members. Finally, our group also contributed to the education of our local community by developing courses that were presented to senior citizens through the FSU Osher Lifelong Learning Institute.
